body:
I have my mission planner, set up OA_type to 1, set serial 1 to mavlink and I am connected through a pi, I am trying to now send obstacle data to my pixhawk for tes,t but for some reason sending this message:

    msg=vehicle.message_factory.distance_sensor_encode(
        0, #time since boot , this is not used
        5, #min distance in centimeters
        1800, #max distance of the sensor in cm
        x, #distance of object detection.
        0, #type 
        1, #onboard id, not used
        y, # sector
        0, # covariance, not used.
        )
    vehicle.send_mavlink(msg)

with values, is not triggering the obstacle detection, the proximity radar on mission planner is not showing any change. Is there a way to fix this or am I using the wrong type of message ?
title: vehicle.message_factory.distance_sensor_encode not working?

this is the code i am trying to run

```
import dronekit
from dronekit import connect, VehicleMode
vehicle = connect("/dev/ttyAMA0",baud = 1500000 , wait_ready =True)
print(" Global Location: %s" % vehicle.location.global_frame)
vehicle.close()
```

I already set up telemetry 2 baudrate and protocol on mission planner.  No idea why its still not connecting.   Anyone else has this issue?

body:
When I upload to the Pixhawk via Mission Planner, and then download it again, there doesnt seem to be any issue. But when I use Dronekit to upload a mission file, it comes back looking very strange.

Here's the (simplified) code I use to upload:
```
upload_mission_file("D:\TestMission.txt")
```

```
# Upload mission file
def upload_mission_file(file_name):
    mission_list = load_mission(file_name)

    # Clear existing mission from vehicle
    print(' Clear mission')
    cmds = communications_global.vehicle.commands
    cmds.clear()

    # Add new mission to vehicle
    for command in mission_list:
        cmds.add(command)

    #for command in cmds:
    #    print(str(command))

    print('Upload mission')
    communications_global.vehicle.commands.upload()
    print("Uploaded mission")
```

```
# Load mission from file
def load_mission(file_name):
    # Load a mission from a file into a list. The mission definition is in the Waypoint file
    # format (http://qgroundcontrol.org/mavlink/waypoint_protocol#waypoint_file_format).
    # This function is used by upload_mission().

    print("\nReading mission from file: %s" % file_name)
    cmds = communications_global.vehicle.commands
    missionlist = []
    with open(file_name) as f:
        for i, line in enumerate(f):
            if i == 0:
                if not line.startswith('QGC WPL 110'):
                    raise Exception('File is not supported WP version')
            else:
                linearray = line.split('\t')
                ln_index = int(linearray[0])
                ln_currentwp = int(linearray[1])
                ln_frame = int(linearray[2])
                ln_command = int(linearray[3])
                ln_param1 = float(linearray[4])
                ln_param2 = float(linearray[5])
                ln_param3 = float(linearray[6])
                ln_param4 = float(linearray[7])
                ln_param5 = float(linearray[8])
                ln_param6 = float(linearray[9])
                ln_param7 = float(linearray[10])
                ln_autocontinue = int(linearray[11].strip())
                cmd = Command(0, 0, 0, ln_frame, ln_command, ln_currentwp, ln_autocontinue, ln_param1, ln_param2,
                              ln_param3, ln_param4, ln_param5, ln_param6, ln_param7)
                missionlist.append(cmd)
    return missionlist
```

--

Here's what I upload:
```
QGC WPL 110
0   1   0   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066668 173.7577779 100 1
1   0   0   178 0.00000000  0.50000000  50.00000000 0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.000000    1
2   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066668 173.7577779 100 0
3   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066667 173.7577778 100 0
4   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066666 173.7577777 100 0
5   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066665 173.7577776 100 0
6   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066664 173.7577775 100 0
7   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066663 173.7577774 100 0
8   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066662 173.7577773 100 0
9   0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066661 173.7577772 100 0
10  0   3   16  0   0   0   0   -41.5066660 173.7577771 100 0
```


And here's what comes back:
```
QGC WPL 110
0   1   0   16  0   0   0   0   -35.363262  149.165237  1168.000000 1
1   0   0   178 0.00000000  0.50000000  50.00000000 0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.000000    1
2   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
3   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
4   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
5   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
6   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
7   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
8   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666880    173.75778560    100.000000  1
9   0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666560    173.75778560    100.000000  1
10  0   3   16  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  0.00000000  -41.50666560    173.75778560    100.000000  1
```

I've read about rounding issues in the official dronekit documentation: https://dronekit-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/mission_import_export.html

However, I've checked right up to the final upload, and there don't seem to be any rounding issues. So unless its something deep in the pymavlink library or on the pixhawk itself (which I doubt because uploading and downloading via mission planner does not cause this issue), I don't think this is the issue.

Anyone have any ideas?

Thanks.
title: [Solved] Upload waypoints weird rounding issue

body:
Hi together, 
in the wiki they say that you should open an issue before trying to use channel override.

Our usecase:
We are a students group developing a drone that should pick objects up. To center on the objects we're setting the vehicle-velocity setting in GUIDED-Mode with dronekit. However, the guided-mode doesn't seem to be suitable for landing, as the motors don't turn off automaticly (we tried it once and the copter flipped and crashed, but that was like 6 months ago). 
That's why we need to use the landing-mode at some point (the copter should center all the way till right before the motors disarm).  However, the landing mode doesn't support the send vehicle-velocity settings, the only option nowadays is to use the channel-override method.

Maybe is there an option we missed to check if the drone has already landed, so that we can use guided-mode? (like in the fc-software). As now I don't see a better way as to use channel-override ([specification for landing mode](https://ardupilot.org/copter/docs/land-mode.html) )
title: Channel override in landing mode

body:
I am working on a project where we are trying to implement communications between 2 drones. The basic structure is: Drone1 sends a command to Drone2 (through UDP and Python Socket) to first arm, then takeoff, and fly to up 5 meters. Drone2 then sends a message to Drone1 to fly up 5 meters. When testing this, the altitude sensors on our drones can be iffy, which results in them flying higher than intended, and after about 30 seconds they end up crashing down. 

We want to create a manual takeover command so we can use our RC Remotes to pilot the drones if something like this were to happen again. It seems like the only way to do this is with channel overrides, which is strongly advised against in the documentation. We are able to run RC commands on the drones, but when running our message code, it seems like the RC is disabled. 

Thank you!!
title: Manual Override

body:
Hey guys! 

When calling `set_attitude_target_encode()` for changing ROLL it works correctly (vehicle moves left/right). But it doesn't work for changing PITCH, I mean it completely ignores the message, and so PITCH stays unchanged. 

MODE: GUIDED
VEHICLE_TYPE: PLANE

Changing ROLL:
```python
q = quaternion.QuaternionBase([np.radians(45), np.radians(0), np.radians(0)])
print(q)
msg = vehicle.message_factory.set_attitude_target_encode(
0,
0,
0,
0b11100010,
q,
0,
0,
0,
0)
vehicle.send_mavlink(msg)
vehicle.flush()
```

Changing PITCH:
```python
q = quaternion.QuaternionBase([np.radians(0), np.radians(45), np.radians(0)])
print(q)
msg = vehicle.message_factory.set_attitude_target_encode(
0,
0,
0,
0b11100010,
q,
0,
0,
0,
0)
vehicle.send_mavlink(msg)
vehicle.flush()
```
title: SITL ignores PITCH changes after set_attitude_target_encode()

Hey,

i'm working with sim_vehicle.py and Gazebo and want to implement an easy RC_override in mode STABILIZE but it seems that i do something wrong.

`time.sleep(3)
print("Set Ch3 override to 1900")
vehicle.channels.overrides[3] = 1900
print(" Channel overrides: %s" % vehicle.channels.overrides)
time.sleep(10)`

The Drone has no reaction to this code, its in stabilize mode and armed. I can override with mavproxy (rc x yyyy) but i want to make it work with dronekit or mavlink only. The MAV command 
`msg = vehicle.message_factory.command_long_encode(0, 0, mavutil.mavlink.MAV_CMD_DO_SET_SERVO, 0, 2, 1900, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0) 
vehicle.send_mavlink(msg)`
shows at least a reaction from SITL: "Channel 2 is already in use"
Its only armed and in stabilized, nothing more.

Any Ideas?
title: [SOLVED] SITL shows no reaction from RC override

body:
I found a bug when updating home location.

There are two ways in which I can update the home location

```
a = vehicle.location.global_frame
a.lat = location_marker.lat
a.lon = location_marker.lon
vehicle.home_location = a
```

Or 

```
newloc = LocationGlobal(marker_lat, marker_lon)
vehicle.home_location = newloc
```

Both the above method works fine.

But when I add altitude also, the Drone lands automatically.

```
a.alt = 0.1
vehicle.home_location = a
```

or 

```
newloc = LocationGlobal(marker_lat, marker_lon, 0.1)
vehicle.home_location = newloc
```

Kindly fix the bug and tell us how can we set the altitude of the home location.
title: Bug while updating home location

body:
Here is the code snippet:

```
def cmdBodyPosition(x, y, z):
    msg = vehicle.message_factory.set_position_target_local_ned_encode(
        0,  # time_boot_ms (not used)
        0, 0,  # target system, target component
        mavutil.mavlink.MAV_FRAME_LOCAL_NED,  # frame
        0b110111111000,  # type_mask
        x, y, z,  # x, y, z positions
        0, 0, 0,  # x, y, z velocity in m/s
        0, 0, 0,  # x, y, z acceleration
        0, 0)  # yaw, yaw_rate (not supported yet, ignored in GCS_Mavlink)
    vehicle.send_mavlink(msg)
    vehicle.flush()
arm_and_takeoff(5)
time.sleep(5)
print vehicle.home_location
cmdBodyPosition(-5, 0, -5)
time.sleep(5)
vehicle.home_location = vehicle.location.global_frame
print vehicle.home_location
time.sleep(5)
cmdBodyPosition(0, 0, 0)
time.sleep(5)
```

According to my understanding of the code, the drone should arm and take off to 5 meters which it does pretty well.
The first home location printed is ```LocationGlobal:lat=-35.3632609,lon=149.1652299,alt=0.584```
After this, drone moves forward for 5 meters maintaining the altitude at 5 meters (expected too)  and new home location is updated(till here it works pretty much well).
```LocationGlobal:lat=-35.3633055,lon=149.165229,alt=588.96```

Now, to my understanding since new home location has been updated, then giving
```cmdBodyPosition(0, 0, 0)``` command should not let drone move from its position. But to the surprise, it maintains its altitude but goes back to its original latitude position.

I have observed that drone moves relative to the Z location when giving ```cmdBodyPosition``` command when home location is updated. But X and Y are relative to the first home location.

Need clarification.
title: Weird working of vehicle.home_location and vehicle.message_factory.set_position_target_local_ned_encode

body:
When handling a drone fleet, it is useful to calibrate the drones from DroneKit's API without resorting to QGroundControl, which requires manual operation.
This is especially true for the calibrations which don't require any manual intervention (gyro, barometer, board level), since they can be carried out on the entire fleet in parallel.

In this PR, I added the support for the calibration of:
1) Magnetometer
2) Accelerometer
3) "Simple accelerometer" calibration
4) Barometer
5) Gyroscope
6) Board level

To test the commands, I developed a generic function able to listen to the `COMMAND_ACK` messages and to assert that a specific command has been ACKed.

The accelerometer calibrations are expected to return the `MAV_RESULT_FAILED` status, since in the SITL there's nobody moving the drone.
Still, it's useful to check the ACK status to make sure that the autopilot does not respond with an "unsupported" or "denied" status.

The magnetometer calibration is expected to return the `MAV_RESULT_UNSUPPORTED` status in the tests because the `MAV_CMD_DO_START_MAG_CAL` is not supported in APM Copter 3.3 (the current version of the SITL), however it is supported in the latest ArduPilot master.
PX4, on the other hand, handles the magnetometer calibration using the standard `MAV_CMD_PREFLIGHT_CALIBRATION` message, so I had to handle the two cases in `Vehicle.calibrate_magnetometer()`.
title: Add commands and tests for sensor calibration

body:
## Current situation
DroneKit does not play well in the logging department when it's used as a library.
Indeed, the user has no way to configure DroneKit's logging apart from monkey-patching (#862).

The logging of MAVLink `STATUSTEXT` messages can be configured by providing a `status_printer` function to `connect()`; however, while the `STATUSTEXT` message [provides](https://mavlink.io/en/messages/common.html#STATUSTEXT) the severity level ([`MAV_SEVERITY` enum](https://mavlink.io/en/messages/common.html#MAV_SEVERITY)) in a field, DroneKit ignores it and prints all the messages from the autopilot with the same severity.

Also, when an exception is encountered in an attribute or message handler, the stack trace does not get printed, making debugging more difficult.

Related issues: #118, #862

## Proposed changes
This PR tries to improve the situation by replacing all the uses of `errprinter()` and `print()` with the built-in Python [`logging`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html) module facilities.
The stack trace is printed (`exc_info=True`) in case of "unexpected" exceptions coming from user's code.

`STATUSTEXT` messages are logged by a separate logger to make it clear which messages are coming from the autopilot and which others are emitted from the DroneKit library; the two loggers may be configured independently.
The `STATUSTEXT` messages are printed with the correct logging level specified by the autopilot: filtering by severity is now possible.
The `status_printer` argument of `connect()` is deprecated.

With the proposed changes, the library user would be able to format, filter, redirect and suppress DroneKit's and the autopilot's log messages at his/her pleasure.

## Logging in tests
A nice side effect of this change is that the tests now run completely silent, because nose [captures](https://nose.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/logcapture.html) all the log messages and prints them only in case of error.

To force the printing of log messages in test output, one can do:
```
nosetests -svx --debug=autopilot,dronekit
```
title: Logging: use builtin logging module for library and autopilot output

body:
Ran `flake8` on the code base and fixed most of the issues, with this patch

```
flake8 --ignore=E501,F811,E722,E262,E221 --exclude=dronekit/lib.py dronekit
```

succeeds without errors.
I also implemented some of the suggestions proposed by PyCharm's code inspection tools (chained comparisons and a documentation inconsistency).
title: PEP8 and style improvements

body:
In `mavlink.py`, in `mavlink_thread_in`, specifically catch and ignore `MAVError` (the sporadic messages "invalid MAVLink prefix..." are all MAVErrors), avoiding to swallow legitimate exceptions with a broad `except` clause.

This patch should make it easier to debug DroneKit + pymavlink as library code for developers: it's very hard to diagnose problems if the program silently fails.
title: mavlink.py: specific exception handling for MAVError

body:
While profiling my DroneKit-based application with yappi, I noticed that the [`MAVLink_message.__eq__()`](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/eaa2ab77e9490f0427d86a2401ab61c99b6bca2b/generator/mavgen_python.py#L165) method was called more than 1.9 million times over a few minutes.
It was the function called with the greatest frequency in the whole application, and consumed a lot of CPU time.
![QCacheGrind: functions by number of calls](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5058646/47753223-17119200-dc97-11e8-8c3c-87bb58cfa155.png)

I inspected the call stack using QCacheGrind and found out that all of these calls were comparisons of a MAVLink message object with `None`. All of them can be avoided by using the idiomatic constructs `is None` / `is not None`.

Some of these calls (~13k) were from pymavlink: these [are already gone](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/pull/235).

![Callers subdivision](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5058646/47753794-1974eb80-dc99-11e8-8b98-9d4ee61b1497.png)

All the other calls are coming from DroneKit, specifically from [this line of code](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/blob/4e392d603818ff29eadf6518122c6418d6c67f95/dronekit/__init__.py#L1285) inside a loop listener (a function executed once every few incoming MAVLink message):
```python
        # list containing 1 item for each parameter of the autopilot:
        #Â each can be None (param not loaded) or a PARAM_VALUE message object
        self._params_set = []
        self._params_loaded = False

        @handler.forward_loop
        def listener(_):
            # HERE: "not in" calls MAVLink_message.__eq__()
            # for each non-None element in self._params_set
            if None not in self._params_set and not self._params_loaded:
                self._params_loaded = True
                self.notify_attribute_listeners('parameters', self.parameters)
```

That code is expensive. The current version of PX4 has more than 500 parameters: even after all the parameters are loaded, on every message loop, DroneKit calls `MAVLink_message.__eq__()` 500+ times!

I improved the code:
```python
            # Exploit short-circuiting of the and operator (check the boolean first)
            # so that, if self._params_loaded == True, the array does not get checked;
            # replace the expensive `__eq__()` call with a fast, idiomatic
            # `is not None` check
            if not self._params_loaded and all(x is not None for x in self._params_set):
```

I went ahead and fixed all the comparisons with `None`, `True`,  `False`, and replaced a double lookup in a dictionary with a `.get()` call.
title: Performance improvements (comparisons with None, True, False)

body:
In the last weeks, pymavlink changed the way it handles strings and bytes in Python 3.
In particular, the `param_request_read_send()` function now accepts the parameter name only as bytes and not as string (references: [1](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/c16da2f26b2d0f19d692e870bbe589e7a39bb6b1), [2](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/5e97b20eeb255a8c956fce9366e71207f00e8484)).

This breaks Python 3 compatibility for DroneKit in some cases, namely when the line of code affected by this PR gets called in the Vehicle initialization phase (initial download of parameters).
I noticed this behaviour in the SITL tests, running on Python 3.7:
* `SITL_SPEEDUP=10 nosetests`: everything is OK, because that line of code never gets called
* `nosetests`: each test gets stuck at the "Calibrating barometer" phase, and times out

With this fix, the tests run correctly under Python 3 in both cases.
title: pymavlink: Python 3 compatibility fix

body:
pymavlink uses non-blocking [sockets](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/master/mavutil.py#L926) and [serial ports](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/master/mavutil.py#L824): polling for data in a while loop with a `sleep(0.05)` is inefficient and leads to increased latency for incoming MAVLink messages (issue #863).

But, if the `sleep` call is blindly removed, then the CPU usage rises to 100% (busy-looping)!

The [`select()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/select.html#select.select) system call, [exposed in the pymavlink API](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/master/mavutil.py#L209), puts the `mavlink_thread_in` thread to sleep for just the right amount of time and wakes it up when fresh data is ready to be processed.

If `select()` is used, the returned message may never be `None`, so the loop listeners would never get called. This is also fixed by ensuring that the loop listeners are called at least every 0.5 s.
title: mavlink.py: efficient I/O waiting with select()

body:
I wrote a simple script to measure the MAVLink message latency (round-trip time) by exploiting the `TIMESYNC` protocol as implemented in PX4.
The protocol works like this: in the client application you send a `TIMESYNC` message to the autopilot, with:
* `tc1=0`;
* `ts1` set to the locally generated timestamp.

The firmware responds ([source code](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/6f204c491335af88dcf1c13484e3d98f82868296/src/modules/mavlink/mavlink_timesync.cpp#L67)) with another `TIMESYNC`, having:
* the same `ts1` field (the timestamp of the original message);
* the autopilot's timestamp in the `tc1` field.

By observing the difference between the timestamp of arrival of the second message and its `ts1` field, you can effectively measure the round-trip time of the message and estimate the link latency (e.g. by assuming latency = RTT / 2).
You can also estimate the offset between the client and the autopilot's clocks using the `tc1` field, but I'm not interested in this right now.

I did the following experiment: send a `TIMESYNC` to the autopilot every 10 ms for 100 times, and measure the round-trip times from the answers.
I'm using the PX4 SITL simulator, so I'm communicating with the autopilot through UDP on the same host (ideal conditions, no packet loss).

I noticed a strange pattern in the measured latencies (**orange line** in the graph).

![timesync latencies rtt _ 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5058646/47603124-c1638e00-d9e7-11e8-80ab-71ae1e8cffde.png)

In the graph we can observe groups of 4-5 messages with strictly decreasing latencies, starting from 25 ms  down to about 5 ms or less.

I also observed the autopilot-generated timestamps (`tc1` field) and noticed that they were very regular (there were about 10 ms between them, always).
So, this must be a problem on the receiving side of the client.

The cause of the problem is [this line of code](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/blob/5d2614f79092cc3ea03062a084579eb16577cd22/dronekit/mavlink.py#L207): `time.sleep(0.05)` in the `mavlink_thread_in` function.

That `sleep()` makes DroneKit wait 50 ms if no messages are found in the buffer; it matches the 25 ms delay shown in the graph (I'm plotting RTT / 2 as a latency estimate).

By removing the sleep, I get dramatically lower latencies (less than 1 ms on average): they are shown on the **blue line** in the above graph.

Why is that sleep there? Is it possible to remove it?
I'd like to do so to obtain a reliable estimate  of the link latency on the autopilot side.
title: High latency in MAVLink message receiving

title: How to MUTE connection logs?

body:
pymavlink has been fixed ([1](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/5e97b20eeb255a8c956fce9366e71207f00e8484), [2](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/4d9c2754c64a7d02fa86b0043335269859e9028a), [3](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/4026f1df0f2bfd0925e307a34af7eaa348e0597d)) to correctly handle strings in both Python 2 and Python 3.

This means that with the latest pymavlink release, the SITL tests are finally passing for Python 3 also.

This PR bumps the pymavlink dependency to the latest stable version and re-enables the CircleCI Python 3 tests.
title: Update pymavlink for Python 3 support

body:
If Vehicle instances are left unclosed, the latest pymavlink (2.2.20) will spam a lot of "EOF on TCP socket" warning messages:
https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/issues/230

This commit fixes the issue and allows DroneKit to be used with the latest pymavlink.
In turn, this will enable full Python 3 compatibility for DroneKit. :-)
title: Properly close Vehicle instances after SITL tests

body:
I cannot connect to pixhawk 2.4.8 through telemetry. 
Using: 
Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, 
dronekit 2.9.1
pymavlink 2.2.10
pyserial 3.4
python 3.5.2

Hardware: I am using a 915MHz telemetry and have tested it in Mission planner and QGroundControl with the exact same set up, have done multiple auto mission with it and haven't gotten any problems. 

I have tried: 
`v= dronekit.connect("/dev/ttyUSB0", baud=57600, wait_ready=True)`
`v= dronekit.connect("/dev/ttyUSB0", baud=57600, rate=10, wait_ready=True)`

`v = dronekit.connect("/dev/ttyUSB0", baud=57600, wait_ready=False)` with
`v.wait_ready(True, timeout=30)` and even 60, 180 and 240

`vehicle = connect("/dev/ttyUSB0", baud=57600, wait_ready=False, heartbeat_timeout=15)`
`vehicle.wait_ready('autopilot_version', timeout=180)`

Output:
with `v= dronekit.connect("/dev/ttyUSB0", baud=57600`, it connects and then gets disconnected right away:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18321830/44896010-9391ef80-acab-11e8-8bc4-2a2eb50adfad.png)
I used ipython there, but I have tried it in terminal and python script.
 Increase timeout will just timeout after a long time. 

I used QGroundContorl with system ID 255 and it connects with no problem. When I test I have made sure that 
- The port exist
- Nothing else is using it
- No Ground Control Software is open

With the same setup successfully using dronekit connecting with:
- Wired connection to pixhawk 
- `vehicle = connect("/dev/ttyACM0", baud=115200, wait_ready=True)`
- Telemetry 2 connection to pixhawk
- `vehicle = dronekit.connect("/dev/ttyUSB0", wait_ready=True, baud=1500000)`
- Any Simulators (sim_vehicle, dronekit, gazebo and Javsim)

Thank you for helping! 
EDIT 1: I downgraded pymavlink to 2.0.6, still cannot connect
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18321830/44901608-b8db2980-acbc-11e8-8f64-643bde446f9d.png)
title: Cannot connect to the vehicle via telemetry

body: There are numerous state attributes of the Pixhawk2.1/Cube (APM:Copter-3.5.5) that Mission Planner displays in its status page that aren't included in the list of [supported attributes using dronekit](http://python.dronekit.io/guide/vehicle_state_and_parameters.html).  As just one example, I would like to be able to read the 'press_abs' variable  (pressure reported by the internal barometer).  Is there any way to do this with the official release of dronekit?
title: Reading 'unsupported' vehicle state attributes?

body: Hi. I noticed that during simulation and real test on the drone, when using the navigation function goto() that implements the MAVLink commands MAV_CMD_NAV_WAYPOINT, the drone cannot reach the exact location of the waypoint and hangs around 10 cm away from the waypoint without further approaching it. As our application needs some accurate actuation, I was wondering where the problem lies in this case and what direction can be looked into to solve it? On the real drone, an EMILD RTK GPS module is used and RTK fix is achieved, so accuracy should not be the problem.
title: About navigation accuracy

body: param1 should have value 0 rather than 2
title: Home location set command corrected, fixes #827

body:
According to the message definitions in [MAVLINK](http://mavlink.org/messages/common), message 179 should use a value of 0 in param1 to set to entered values.

The home location setter uses a value of 2, which is ignored by Ardupilot.
title: Home location setter forms invalid command
